He was reported to say everyone loves Mrs.

2197.text:
Madison and, of course, she responded, that's
because Mrs. Madison loves everybody. It wasn't

2203.text:
strictly speaking true. She actually was better
at keeping a grudge than James was. But it

2210.text:
seemed to be true. And as we know in politics,
that's far more were than what is true.

2217.text:
The Madisons freely mixed foreigners and federalists
and Republicans, producing a social swirl

2223.text:
that allowed the sinus of policy and politics
to form in an informal setting, sometimes

2231.text:
that's a terribly valuable opportunity. Office
seekers would come to Dolly and ask her to

2239.text:
intercede with the President to get jobs.
And as near as we can tell, she was pretty

2244.text:
good at it.
In fact, she really was a political partner,

2252.text:
always a loyal and sure-footed one who not
only warmed his private life but also helped

2258.text:
him forge a new Republican style for the nation.
Indeed, the losing federalist candidate in

2264.text:
1808 claimed he had lost to Mr. and Mrs. Madison.
"I might have had a better chance had I faced

2271.text:
Mr. Madison alone."
So many of you will recall Dolly's shining

2277.text:
moment during the War of 1812 which came actually
on James' worst day probably of his entire

2286.text:
career. In late August of 1814, British Army
had been disembarked from ships in the Chesapeake

2296.text:
Bay, marched on Washington. There was a very
brief skirmish at Bladensburg. Sometimes referred

2305.text:
to as the Bladensburg races because our militia
ran so quickly. Madison had gone to the field

2313.text:
to rally the troops and inspire them but it
was just not something that he was going to

2319.text:
be able to do. And the militia wasn't ever
going to be inspired anyway.

2325.text:
So the British marched into Washington and
they burned the public buildings. This is

2330.text:
a black mark on his presidency which sometimes
I think has caused him to be underestimated

2336.text:
over the years. But there was a shining moment
which is right before the British got there,

2343.text:
Dolly who had to flee remembered to take down
the portrait of George Washington. We were

2351.text:
a republic. We were not a monarchy. We didn't
have crown jewels. But we did cherish the

2356.text:
memory of George Washington. And this was
a presence of mind, a spirit, a redoubtable

2365.text:
attitude which was much valued through the
country. James Madison was reviled by many

2372.text:
of his countrymen after the burning of Washington's
public buildings. He was called a coward repeatedly.

2381.text:
But people kept a warm spot in their hearts
for Dolly.

2384.text:
Now, their retirement at Montpellier was generally
a happy one but a dark cloud formed increasingly

2396.text:
over it. He lived for almost -- James lived
for almost 20 years in retirement. He lived

2402.text:
to be 85. For a fellow who was sick much his
life, it was a surprise to him that he lived

2408.text:
so long. And that dark shadow was slavery.
I was struck that it is so rarely remarked

2417.text:
upon that Madison's grandfather was poisoned
to death by his own slave. This is an episode

2426.text:
that Madison never commented on and one has
to assume was not really talked about at Montpellier.

2436.text:
Madison often lived there with five or six
or seven other white people and about a hundred

2442.text:
black slaves.
But I think we can assume also that all of

2449.text:
the white people and all of the black people
knew that story, and it created a very corrosive

2455.text:
environment. Madison's opinion of slavery
was of abhorrence. He struggled between his

2468.text:
commitments to human liberty and the fact
that he lived on the labor of slaves. He bought

2473.text:
land in upstate New York and he wrote a friend
that he hoped to move there and never to rely

2480.text:
upon the labor of slaves. He didn't do it.
We don't know exactly why, the pull of his

2489.text:
family, the pull of his success. It seems
to me as he gets into the core of his public

2498.text:
career, he is able to put these feelings about
slavery aside and he simply doesn't confront

2506.text:
them.
But then in retirement, he can't look away

2512.text:
anymore. It is there every day in Montpellier.
It is all around him. And he's living into

2521.text:
an era, the Missouri compromise, the rise
of abolitionism, and that rebellion in 1831.

2527.text:
160 people are slaughtered as part of that
rebellion. He now can see what he's always

2534.text:
predicted as a young man. He predicted that
slavery was the one thing that could tear

2539.text:
the nation apart, and now he could see that
it is coming.

2543.text:
And he almost compulsively tried to figure
out a way out of the box, how do we fix slavery?

2549.text:
And he's a creature of intellect, more on
policy issues. He figured out how to set up

2557.text:
a government. He figured out how to take on
the British. And he wants to figure out slavery.

2562.text:
And he writes memos to himself. Well, we can
sell off all the land out west that's owned

2569.text:
by the government and we will use that money
to pay the slave owners. We have to get the

2574.text:
slaves out of the country because prejudice
is so bad that they will have terrible lives

2578.text:
if they stay here. We will just have more
violence. So we have to then get them over

2582.text:
to Africa or South America or anywhere else.
And it is a poignant, terrible, disturbing

2594.text:
spectacle. This great statesmen grappling
with this issue that he can't solve because

2602.text:
he is failing to see it for what it really
is, which is a failure of the human heart

2610.text:
that is prejudice at its core. That is why
he can't solve it.

2617.text:
Indeed, one of the sort of pathetic things
he does -- this is at Montpellier.If you visited,

2625.text:
and I encourage you to, they have done a wonderful
job restoring his place. They are reconstructing

2631.text:
slave cabins he built late in his life. It
was customary, of course, to have your slaves

2636.text:
live somewhere where nobody could see them
because they didn't live very nicely. They

2643.text:
were kept in poor conditions. Well, Madison
built essentially a Village of slave cottages.

2652.text:
He got tired of having northerners and Europeans
come and lecture him about slavery. So he

2657.text:
built these nice slave cabins. They were sort
of duplexes with glass windows and hung doors.

2666.text:
And it was to show people that slavery wasn't
so bad. And it is pretty sad, frankly, that

2675.text:
that was the best he was able to manage.
He never did free any of his slaves. Indeed,

2685.text:
Dolly despite her Quaker background leaves
not a word spoken ever about slavery. So we

2692.text:
don't actually know what she thought either.
In his final years, James became increasingly

2700.text:
decrepit. I love this image of him two years
before he died. He spent his days in his dressing

2705.text:
gown and night cap. He really lived in two
rooms at Montpellier. But his mind remained

2713.text:
bright, his intellect sharp. These years were
hard on Dolly. She had to take care of him

2719.text:
all the time. She wrote once that his hands
and fingers are sill so swelled and sore to

2726.text:
be nearly useless but I lend him mine.
He could always be happy with ideas or at

2734.text:
least occupied with ideas and newspapers and
books. She needed people and it was hard for

2739.text:
her to be isolated without them. When he died
in 1836 at the age of 85, she moved back to

2747.text:
Washington City and reentered the social world.
And we got this wonderful blessing which is

2754.text:
she lived long enough to have her photograph
taken. This is taken just a year or so before

2760.text:
she died in the Zachary Taylor administration.
Her reentry into the social life was applauded.

2771.text:
She had a good time for few years but then
the money ran out. Financial management was

2780.text:
not among her gifts. She had her own son who
was a bit of a waster and burned up a lot

2787.text:
of money, too. She ended up in a sort of Gentile
poverty with only a couple of slaves who were

2793.text:
sold upon her death.
Now, having held forth on two of Madison's

2799.text:
productive partnerships or just one of them,
actually, I want to close with a note about

2805.text:
Madison himself. I do think he was able to
form these partnerships because of who he

2812.text:
was. He was not the dry creature of intellect
that we sometimes think of. He was referred

2817.text:
to by a contemporary as I have never seen
so much mind and so little matter.

2822.text:
(laughter).
But he had a genuineness and an integrity

2825.text:
and open-heartedness. These qualities for
me shine through in the way he received the

2831.text:
news of the Treaty of Ghent which is the agreement
that ended the War of 1812. As I said, he

2837.text:
pushed the nation into war and it didn't go
terribly well much of the time. It's February

2845.text:
13, 1815. Just about 200 years before now.
He's actually living in an octagon house which

2853.text:
still stands over on 17th Street. A rumor
arrives that the treaty has been signed with

2861.text:
Britain and that Pennsylvania senator rushes
to Octagon House to ask Madison if it is true.

2867.text:
Let me just read a short passage from the
book.

2871.text:
"the senator found the house dark, the President
sitting solitary in his parlor. In perfect

2877.text:
tranquility. Not even a servant in waiting.
The senator asked if the rumor was true. Madison

2884.text:
bad him sit down. I will tell you all I know,
he said. Then confirmed that he thought there

2892.text:
was peace but he had no official confirmation.
The senator recalled with some wonder what

2898.text:
he called the President's self-command on
the occasion and greatness of mind."

2905.text:
The War of 1812 truly had been Mr. Madison's
war, as his opponents called it. It was about

2912.text:
principles, not gain. It was fought with a
quiet tenacity, sometimes ineptly and with

2919.text:
endless tolerance of those who opposed it.
As a friend of Madison's wrote years later,

2925.text:
the war had been conducted in perfect keeping
with the character of the President of whom

2931.text:
it may be said that no one had to a greater
extent firmness, mildness and self-possession.

2938.text:
And when peace came, Madison welcomed it in
a darkened house alone with his thoughts.

2959.text:
Thank you. I would be happy to take questions
but it is great if you could make your way

2963.text:
to one of the microphones.
>> Thank you for that informative presentation.

2972.text:
In the dim recesses of my memory, I remember
writing a paper in college. I think it was

2975.text:
about a landmark case, was it Marbury versus
Madison. Can you refresh my memory? I don't

2982.text:
recall any specifics.
>> David Stewart: Really?

2990.text:
(laughter).
It's kind of an accident that his name is

2993.text:
on the case. It was because he was Secretary
of State. The case involved the midnight judges

3000.text:
of John Adams. At the very end of Adams' administration,
he appoints a bunch of judges in the last

3009.text:
24-hours before he leaves office. And they
are not able to take their commissions and

3016.text:
have them confirmed and take office. So when
Jefferson becomes President, these judges

3024.text:
show up and Mr. Marbury was to be some sort
of officer in the District of Columbia. They

3032.text:
go to the Secretary of State and say, okay,
here's our commission. We are now in office.

3037.text:
And Madison said, no, you're not.
And they brought suit saying they were entitled

3042.text:
to the office. This ends up -- it takes two
years to litigate, God bless the lawyers.

3050.text:
And it ends up before Chief Justice Marshall
who rules in Madison's favor and in favor

3056.text:
of Jefferson saying these judges can't take
office. But it does so on such a technicality.

3063.text:
And after basically holding that -- the courts
have the right to judge the Constitutionality

3070.text:
of every federal statute that Jefferson hates
the ruling.

3075.text:
So I'm pretty sure my federal jurisdiction
professor would be appalled by that description

3080.text:
of the case. But that's a quick description.
>> Thank you very much.

3083.text:
>> David Stewart: Yes, sir?
>> Thanks also for a wonderful presentation.

3088.text:
You stress the rigger of Madison's intellect.
What was his formal education, where and how?

3098.text:
>> David Stewart: He was sent away to a secondary
school which he resided at. He was largely

3107.text:
taught by Scotts which in America was in that
era the best way to be taught. There was a

3114.text:
lot of Scotts who had come overlooking for
opportunity who were very well-educated and

3120.text:
were fine instructors.
He then did not do what most Virginia young

3127.text:
gentlemen would do which is to go to the College
of William and Mary. His family sent him to

3132.text:
Princeton which was also run by Scotts.
This had two effects. It put him in the influence

3143.text:
group of John Witherspoon who was President
of the school at the time and other instructors

3147.text:
who were engaged with the Scottish enlightenment
and it exposed to a non-Virginia culture.

3156.text:
I think it was a very formative experience
for him. And all these Scotts were Presbyterians.

3163.text:
They were a minority, a somewhat discriminated
against minority. And I think it gave him

3169.text:
a heightened sense in how minorities can be
picked on by majorities. So it was a terribly

3175.text:
important experience. He finished Princeton
in two years and then stayed for a third year

3183.text:
of graduate study but worked himself into
a breakdown.

3189.text:
And the rest of his life his intellectual
self-discipline is kind of staggering. He

3195.text:
would -- the year before the Constitutional
Convention, he basically trained himself to

3203.text:
be a lawyer. He had never practiced law. He
didn't have any need to or interest in it.

3208.text:
But he knew he had to understand law to do
what he wanted to do in setting up the government.

3213.text:
So he just read everything there was to know
about British and civil law.

3219.text:
He always had this ability with incredible
powers of concentration. He was very obsessive

3225.text:
about his work. He did tend to work himself
sick. That was a pattern also in his life.

3234.text:
>> Thank you. The founders were opposed to
a standing Army and they preferred state militias.

3244.text:
With respect to the Second Amendment, from
your research and from your background, would

3252.text:
Madison's interpretation of the Second Amendment
be in conformity with the Heller case?

3258.text:
>> David Stewart: It's not an easy question
to answer. Let me answer something easier

3266.text:
first, which is the attitude towards the standing
Army, you are exactly right. They terribly

3271.text:
mistrusted it. As did Madison. It was his
attitude.

3277.text:
When he was President during the War of 1812,
he discovered, in fact, the militia was a

3281.text:
lousy way to fight a war. We had militia when
we wanted to invade Canada they would stop

3287.text:
at the border and say "I didn't sign up for
that." And they were not well-trained, by

3294.text:
definition. They could not stand up to British
regulars. And at the end of the war with his

3301.text:
first budget after the war, he says to Congress,
he issues -- sends a statement in his budget

3307.text:
and says we do need to have an Army. I was
wrong. You really do need an Army. So he was

3314.text:
-- his opinion was changed on that subject.
The question to the Second Amendment is not

3319.text:
an easy one because he never commented on
it. He had no reason to. It was never a disputed

3326.text:
subject in his life time. So you are just
left with the text of the amendment. It wasn't

3331.text:
really debated in Congress when the Second
Amendment goes through Congress. We only have

3336.text:
records from the House because the Senate
met in secret in those days and we have nothing

3341.text:
for what they did.
My sense is that there's so much about the

3347.text:
modern world that Madison could not have imagined
that the proliferation of guns in an urban

3355.text:
society would surprise him. He grew up on
the frontier, a society that had guns and

3363.text:
needed guns. There were Indiana scares around
his house when he was a boy. There was violence

3370.text:
everywhere. The French and Indian War was
in his childhood.

3374.text:
So he did not have a negative attitude about
guns. And would he feel the same way today?

3381.text:
Hard to say. I think we can't do much better
frankly than fall back on the language of

3388.text:
the amendment.
>> Thank you. If you don't mind. I would just

3394.text:
like to add an addendum to your response to
the question about Marbury versus Madison

3398.text:
because I think it is probably one of the
three or four most important cases the Supreme

3403.text:
Court ever decided in 1806 because it laid
the foundation for the continued power of

3409.text:
the Supreme Court right up until today to
declare acts of Congress and federal treaties

3415.text:
and everything that the states do, if they're
ever challenged in the courts, unconstitutional.

3421.text:
The Supreme Court's original jurisdiction
-- excuse me. Congress had passed The Judiciary

3426.text:
Act of 179 which was the act under which Marbury
brought his suit. In that act, Congress expanded

3434.text:
the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
which otherwise is provided for only in the

3439.text:
Constitution.
>> David Stewart: We need to stick with Madison

3445.text:
Well, this is about Marbury versus Madison.
So it is about Madison. But it is a very extremely

3451.text:
important case.
>> David Stewart: It is absolutely, and possibly

3453.text:
the most important. I would also emphasize
that it was anticipated very much by Hamilton

3460.text:
federalist paper number 78 which also does
talk about judicial review. I think it was

3464.text:
not an unanticipated outcome. I think many
of the Framers intended it.

3471.text:
>> Doug Stewart, white, fascinating, thank
you. Two quick ones. First, Dolly and then

3480.text:
Madison for a quick one. Did Dolly -- which
southern plantation did she grow up? Just

3491.text:
curious.
>> David Stewart: I wish you hadn't asked.

3495.text:
There's arguments about this. North Carolina
puts in a claim for her. I found only evidence

3503.text:
of Virginia locations. It is not even clear
if her father owned the plantation or if he

3508.text:
was a manager or was leasing the plantations.
It's not clear.

3515.text:
>> Okay. Then she had been a mentor so to
speak for a number of women because of her

3525.text:
(inaudible). That's just fascinating what
she did. Madison himself, the main thing besides

3533.text:
the brilliance and his influence which doesn't
get there with the other grates, but did he

3543.text:
ever cross paths with Benjamin Franklin?
>> David Stewart: I didn't understand --

3547.text:
>> Did Madison ever cross paths with Benjamin
Franklin?

3550.text:
>> David Stewart: Did Madison cross paths
with Ben Franklin? Certainly during the Constitutional

3555.text:
Convention. He made it a point of cultivating
Franklin. He went to Franklin's house many

3563.text:
times during the convention and basically
was sit at his knee and ask him questions

3569.text:
and listen to him and have him tell stories.
He admired him tremendously. He was young

3575.text:
enough to be Franklin's grandson. There was
a big age difference. But it was somebody

3582.text:
he valued. They were never peers, of course.
But for that one period, they did have a lot

3589.text:
>> David Stewart: You bet. Last question here?
>> I wonder if you thought that a slave in

3599.text:
the White House by Paul Jennings gives any
light, can you comment on that at all?

3604.text:
>> David Stewart: The question relates to
there was a book a couple years ago "A Slave

3608.text:
in the White House" which are recollections
of Paul Jennings, who was Madison's valet

3615.text:
in the White House. He became a slave to the
Madisons when he was about 8. And ultimately

3625.text:
bought his way out of slavery with Dolly after
James died using money that was loaned to

3632.text:
him by Daniel Webster. And he became a free
man and a self-supporting individual here.

3645.text:
His family descendants still live in the area.
And it is an impressive story about Jennings,

3652.text:
again, a disappointing story about the Madisons
that the only way out was to buy your way
